The second catastrophe …

The ZIPRA paramilitary guerrillas were based in the neighboring country of Zambia to the north, consequently the white Rhodesians clamored for a massive retaliatory strike against the insurgent bases in that country, however the first external target hit by the security forces following the “Hunyani” shoot-down was the prominent cluster of ZIPRA guerrilla bases around the town of Chimoio in the Republic of Mozambique; the former Portuguese colony that is Rhodesia’s eastern neighbor.

The Rhodesian military had originally struck these bases methodically in November 1977 during “Operation Dingo”, obliterating much of the ZIPRA presence there, but the insurgents had since built a complex called “New Chimoio”, slightly to the east; the new camps were distributed across a far larger area than the originals.

In a combined airborne-ground assault called “Operation Snoopy”, the Rhodesian Air Force, the Rhodesian Light Infantry Regiment and the elite Special Air Service (SAS) totally wiped out “New Chimoio” on 20 September 1978. This was followed by the launch of “Operation Gatling” on 19 October 1978. It was another joint-force operation between the Air Force (Canberra bombers, Hawker Hunter fighters, Lynx Rheims – Cessna ground attack aircraft and “K-Car” Alouette III gun ship helicopters) and the Army, which contributed troopers from the elite Rhodesian Special Air Service (SAS) “C” Squadron and Rhodesian Light Infantry “Parabats” paratroopers.

Gatling’s primary target, just 16 kilometers (10 miles) north-east of central Lusaka, was the “Westlands Farm” complex of buildings, which had been transformed into ZIPRA’s main headquarters and training base under the name “Freedom Camp”. ZIPRA presumed that Rhodesia would never attack a site so close to the Zambian capital, Lusaka. About 4,000 guerrillas were undergoing training at the camp with Cuban instructor’s and high-ranking ZIPRA staff also on site.

The Rhodesian operation’s supplementary targets were Chikumbi, 19 kilometers (12 miles) north of Lusaka, and Mkushi Camp; all three were to be attacked simultaneously in an audacious coordinated sweep across Zambia. Assaulting targets deep inside Zambia was a first for the Rhodesian forces; previously only guerrillas near the border had been attacked.

The strike leader was Squadron Leader (equivalent to Lieutenant -Colonel in the US Air Force) Christopher “Chris” John Taylor Dixon, of Number 5 Squadron, Rhodesian Air Force; Dixon’s call-sign was ““Green Leader””. He was piloting a 1950’s-era English Electric Canberra B-2 Bomber‎ and ‎Reconnaissance aircraft.

The Rhodesian Air Force assets flew into Zambia at exceedingly low altitudes (thereby avoiding Zambian radar) and seized total control of Zambia’s airspace (about the size of Texas) for about a quarter of an hour during the initial assault on Westlands Farm. The exchange of radio traffic between Wing Commander Dixon and the Lusaka Airport (LUN) air traffic controller have become legendary as the iconic ““Green Leader” communication …

“Green Leader”: “Lusaka tower, this is “Green Leader”. How do you read? (No answer). Lusaka tower, this is “Green Leader”

Lusaka tower: “Station calling tower?”

“Green Leader”: “Lusaka tower this is “Green Leader”. This is a message for the station commander at Mumbwa from the Rhodesian Air Force. We are attacking the terrorist base at Westlands Farm. This attack is against Rhodesian dissidents and not against Zambia. Rhodesia has no quarrel, repeat, no quarrel with Zambia or her security forces. We therefore ask you not to intervene or oppose our attack. However, we are orbiting your airfield at this time and are under orders to shoot down any Zambian Air Force aircraft, which does not comply with this request and attempts to take off. Did you copy all that?

Lusaka tower: “Copied”.

“Green Leader”: “Roger … thanks. Cheers!”

The Zambians obeyed all of the “Green Leader” and other directives unconditionally; they made no attempt to counterattack and also temporarily halted all domestic and foreign civil air traffic across the entire country. The Zambian Air Force’s Russian supplied Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17 and MiG-19 fighter jets flown by Egyptian Air Force trained pilots did not move from the Mumbwa Air Force station (just west of the capital Lusaka) as instructed by “Green Leader”.

The Rhodesian military sustained relatively minor casualties during the three days of “Operation Gatling”. One soldier, Lance -Corporal Jeffrey Donald Collett – 729660 – “C” Squadron, 22 SAS, Number One Special Air Services Regiment was killed and two “K-Car” helicopter gun ship pilots, Air Force Lieutenants Mark Dawson and Roelf Oeloffse, were slightly wounded in their legs.

The Rhodesians claimed to have killed over 1,500 ZIPRA personnel, as well as some “dozen or so” Cuban instructors. The Zambian government also reported a further 1,348 ZIPRA guerrillas were wounded and 198 were missing. Exhaustive research and careful cross-checking shows that the casualty numbers stated here are fairly consistent across numerous sources. The Rhodesians did acknowledge that there were also heavy civilian casualties; guerrillas’ family members and other visitors camped out in tent and lean-to shack communes near the targeted bases.

The story of a little known World War I tragedy and the lesson that may perhaps have been learned from it; or perhaps not …

In naval tradition it is said that the ships’ bell symbolizes the “soul” of a ship.

I envision, by a similar logical progression, that it is safe to say that truth is the “heart” of a historical narrative. I am going to use the symbolism of the former to illustrate and debate the latter. If details, facts or circumstances are purposefully omitted, denied, misrepresented or glossed over then, undisputedly, truth; and tragically our society become the first victims.

During the First World War, on the 21st of February, 1917, a ship sank near St. Catherine’s Point off the Isle of Wight, killing 616 South African passengers. The sinking of the Royal Mail Ship (R M S) Mendi is one of the worst maritime disasters in United Kingdom waters of the 20th century. Yet very few in South Africa, the United Kingdom or anywhere else in the world have ever heard of it.

Why were these 616 (and many more of their comrades) South African men … black South Africa men (of the 5th Battalion of the South African Native Labour Corps) … sailing from Cape Town at the southern tip of Africa to the Port of Le Havre in France? Like hundreds of thousands of His Majesty’s subjects from every country in the British Empire, they were travelling to become conscripted cannon-fodder to the maelstrom in France. They were desperately needed to replace the hordes of young men that successive irresponsible and fatuous British Generals had sent to certain death by clinging to reckless, heartless and antediluvian strategies and battlefield tactics.

The tale of the R M S Mendi was only safeguarded by oral history; approximately 200 men survived the collision with another steamship, the S. S. Darro (which never stopped to help with the rescue). The survivors were able to recount their stories, ensuring that those who died would not become yet another historical absence, an unknown group of mainly black men at the bottom of the English Channel.

The survivors all described the actions and words of a black Army Chaplain, the Reverend Isaac Dyobha who called the men together as the R M S Mendi started to sink; what he said is the stuff of legends.

He said “Be quiet and calm, my countrymen, for what is taking place now is exactly what you came to do. You are going to die, that is what you came to do. Brothers, we are drilling the drill of death. I, a Xhosa, say you are all my brothers, Zulus, Swazis, Pondos, Bausutos, we die like brothers. We are the sons of Africa. Raise your cries, brothers, for though they made us leave our assegais [spears] at our kraals [villages], our voices are left with our bodies.”

The men took off their boots, stamped their feet and raised imaginary spears and shields to the skies and performed an African dance of death.

The then Prime Minister Louis Botha brought the tragedy to the attention of the South African Parliament; however, the impact to the country was ephemeral as majority political disenfranchisement and vindictive minority (white) rule, later called “apartheid” became the hateful and inhuman doctrine in 20th-century South Africa.

Persistent discrimination ensured that the appalling R M S Mendi tragedy was never afforded rightful recognition by respective Governments in South Africa and the United Kingdom. South African officials during these years demonstrated their unwillingness to highlight black people’s wartime contributions by refusing medals and reasonable post-war recompense to ‘non-combatant men’ or their families, deemed less valuable due to racial prejudice.

Fortunately this callous censorship of Black South African’s contribution to World War I (and all other subsequent military campaigns) has ceased. After Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela became the President of South Africa on the 10th of May, 1994, Mendi memorials now exist in Port Elizabeth (New Brighton), Cape Town (University of Cape Town at Mobray) and Johannesburg (Atteridgeville in Soweto).

Memorial services are now held countrywide and form part of the South African National Defense Force’s Armed Forces Day (Mendi Day). Awards and decorations for Bravery in the name of the Mendi have been issued.

The South African Navy has named two ships in honor of the men who perished … the SAS Mendi (a Valour class MEKO A-200SAN Anti-submarine / Anti-aircraft Frigate) and the SAS Isaac Dyobha (a Warrior class Sandock-Austral Missile-armed Strike-craft). A dedicated exhibit has now also been opened at the South African War Memorial and Museum at Delville Wood, east of the village of Longueuil, in the Department of the Somme in France.

A wreath laying ceremony was held on the 23rd of August 2004, when the recently launched SAS Mendi and the Royal Navy destroyer HMS Nottingham, met at St. Catherine’s Point off
